ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Specific models, history

I learned a lot about exchange rates, international economics, and finance and how investors/central banks act in the world. We also learned applications of this information awards the end of the class.

I learned how to model the asset market and the foreign exchange markets. I learned how recessions can affect currency crises, banking crises, and sovereign debt crises. I learned how the central banks' tools, monetary and fiscal policy, differ under fixed and floating exchange rates. I also learned some national accounting skills and knowledge.
I learned about international financial markets, especially the foreign exchange market.
very good holistic approach of international markets such as exchange rates, interest rates, etc.

You learn about the economic research surrounding international capital markets and flows. Many of the lectures cover topics that are topical, and it's interesting to see the content of each lecture become borne out in the world.

This course taught accounting practices to think about international finance and models to illustrate the role of money markets and the foreign exchange market. We used these models to examine fixed exchange rates and floating exchange rates and the implications of each. We then altered each model by changing variables to understand their dynamics and implications for other world economies and markets.
Amazing knowledge about exchange rates, interest rates, the FED, policies, and inflation.
I developed keen insights into the functioning if international financial markets

International accounting (current account, trade balance, GDP/GNP). How to model money market and foreign exchange markets. How to model aggregate supply and demand curves that incorporate exchange rates and output (AA/DD curves). Floating and pegged exchange rates (advantages and disadvantages of each). International financial history (how the EU and EMU were formed, the gold standard, the US as a reserve currency).
Learned about international finance models for exchange rates and trade
The course offers a great overview to international finance without being too mathematically difficult. Perfect for more macro interested economics majors.
The mechanics behind many phenomenon I knew about in international finance, but did not know the specific economics underpinning them (capital flight, current account imbalances, etc)
A great class to gain a deeper insight into international economics.

Learned about national accounting, the interconnections between the asset, exchange, and money markets, and many about the history of international macroeconomics.
A lot of practical usage of macroeconomics concepts.
Really interesting to learn about the past history.

I learned about foreign exchange markets, exchange rates, monetary and fiscal policy, capital flows, financial crises, monetary history (gold standard, Bretton Woods, etc), and current events (EU, developing countries).
international finance

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Topics are very interesting and much more applicable to the real world than other econ classes
Weaknesses: Much of the class is model-based but then the last unit is history-heavy which was a weird addition in my opinion
Well-organized

Strengths - Professor Fieler tried hard to get to know us and explained the information very well. The material is incredibly interesting and the class is well facilitated for learning. The psets were very helpful practice for the exams.

Weakness - I think the general class would have participated more and been more engaged if the class were not at 9 a.m.

Strengths were the slides and professor who teaches fairly thoroughly, although having the textbook was a great aid in the class as well. Strengths were also having psets that were graded for completion to help me understand the content but without a lot of stress. Weaknesses were 9am in Watson.
It teaches concepts not explored fully in earlier classes. Not much weakness.
no final exam during final period which was really nice! weakness was that there are 3 midterms

The lecture and problem set material is not especially difficult if you pay attention in the lectures. The concepts flow together logically and throughout the semester you will feel your understanding of international capital flows grow. One weakness of the class is that it follows the textbook very closely throughout the semester. This can make lectures less dynamic and interesting than they otherwise would be.

The strengths of the course are the breadth of concepts covered and the depth for which I truly understand the workings of monetary and fiscal policy in the context of money and foreign exchange markets. The course could be improved by making the notes and slides more clear and easy to understand. Often times I would go to the textbook ex-post learning about a topic in class and be surprised by how simply the book was able to explain the concept.

Strengths: Professor Fieler is a very clear and organized lecturer. Her problem sets and exams are very fair. The content of the course moves in a cohesive manner and at a reasonable pace. Each lecture builds on previous ones and forms a very comprehensive picture in the end (ie when we first learned the foreign exchange + money market graphs, and then learned the AA/DD curves, which incorporates those graphs). 

Weaknesses: None! This is a fantastic course for learning the basics about international trade/finance.
Great Professor. Very kind and goes the extra mile to help students.

The strengths were that the materials were interesting and the tests were straightforward, which came out to an enjoyable experience.

I did think that the lectures could have been better delivered in terms of organization, as it was highly dependent on what the professor wanted to review or felt that needed to be covered more irregardless of what was on the slides.
Very well organized and we generally ran ahead of schedule! A little boring at times but generally rewarding. Problem sets were graded for completion which was huge.
Professor Fieler makes this class a must-take. She really cares about the success of the students.
Very systematic course, and a lot of interconnectedness.

Strengths: The course followed the textbook directly and the teacher was accessible
Weaknesses: Sometimes it was a bit slide heavy and also the psets were a bit ambiguous sometimes
interesting content, engaging professor; the problem sets are helpful; the exams can be rough to review for

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, very interesting topics, low workload, and a good professor! If you like exchange rates, and discussing topics relevant to real-world international finance and trade def take.
yes

Yes if you are interested in international economics/finance, emerging markets, and/or central banks.  I was immensely interested in these topics and found the class fascinating and very comprehensive. The model learned in this class has forever improved my understanding of international finance.
Yes if you need a senior Econ seminar. It's fairly chill, just weekly graded for completion psets and 3 exams. The content is interesting if you liked Macroeconomics.
Yes, the course teaches valuable concepts for all students, especially Econ majors.
good econ elective, interesting, and the psets are graded for completion

Yes, it's a great way to learn about an interesting topic as part of your senior year econ requirements. If you have no exposure to finance or international economics, this class may be much less interesting to you.

I would recommend this course to someone only if they have a previous understanding of accounting and an interest in learning about money and foreign exchange markets. This course requires paying acute attention to the variable that change a model and how they change it. I believe that this is a helpful course to understand monetary policy, fiscal policy, money markets, and foreign exchange markets, but a student may not get the knowledge of international finance relations that they were hoping.
Yes, I learned more interesting information than in micro and macro.

Yes for sure!! International Finance is a very organized and fascinating class that gives you a robust foundation for understanding international economic news. After taking this class, a lot of news headlines about international inflation and exchange rates make so much more sense to me. In addition, Professor Fieler is absolutely wonderful. She's a great lecturer and gives very manageable assignments and exams. Would highly recommend this course to every Econ student!
Yes, I would recommend. Very fair workload and you learn interesting stuff that you won't have explored in prior Econ coursework.

I recommend this course if you have any interest in how capital flows throughout the world and how that affects national policies. 
It is not a difficult economic course in terms of quantitative analysis so its very much accessible for most people as well.
Yes if you are interested in learning the models behind phenomena like currency crises, capital flight, banking crises, etc etc
Want to learn something about international macroeconomics, definitely take the course!

Yes if you want to learn about exchange rates, monetary and fiscal policy, etc. There's nothing mind-blowing here. You learn what's in the syllabus and if that interests you you should take the course.
yes if they are interested in the topic
